text:
Yeah, the 28 is
a perfect number. And I doubt if I can
give a perfect lecture.

But I do have a lot of
good stories to tell, so I'll do my best
to understand.

And I guess the first
thing I should say is the big news that is
those of you who wish

to give Christmas presents. Yesterday, I sent the insides
of this book to my publisher.

And so it's possible
now to order pre-copies.

I don't think they'll have
them printed by Christmas, but at least they
have the cover design.

[LAUGHTER] And the official publication
date, I think, is February 3.

But inside the book, it
says printed in January. But anyway, I'm quite
happy that this book--

well, I had lots of
people helping me,

and I worked I worked on
this for the last five years. It was my main project.

So it's called
constraint satisfaction. And that means that if
you have constraints,

you have satisfaction. [LAUGHTER] Now, the next thing is
the title of my talk today

was Strong Components
and Weak Components. And everything that I don't
cover today or that I get wrong

is spelled out better in
this pre-fascicle 12A.

So this is volume 4 Fascicle 7. The first fascicles became
published in hardcover as volume

4A and volume 4B. This is going to be the
first third of volume 4C. And then, if I live
long enough, this

is going to be someday
Fascicle 12 or the first part of fascicle 12.

And who knows how long
the force will be with me.

But anyway, I'm going to
keep telling these stories as long as I can.

So the full story is here, and
you can find it on the web.

And afterwards, I'm going
to put on my website links to it so it's easy
for you to get it.

And there's also some
computer programs that I'm going to talk
about, and those-- I'll put links to all that
stuff on my website afterward.

Now, the strong components
and weak components

are described in this, and
I guess I should mention-- I don't know.

Let me see if Ronnie can zoom
in on this footnote here.

But there's a subtitle
to this lecture, and that is, which algorithm
do you love the most?
And so I don't know. I guess I can zoom in anyway.

OK, so here it says, "Over the
years, I've often been asked, "What is your
favorite algorithm?" Immediately, I
think of how I hate

to be asked to choose
favorites, but then I realized in this particular
case, the answer is clear. Tarjan's algorithm
for strong components

is, without doubt, the
algorithm that I love best. When I learned of this
elegant procedure in 1973,

I understood for the first time
that data structures can also be "deep."

So the topic really is-- it's not only an algorithm,
but it's data structure.

The way that we can organize
the representation of the graphs

that we're dealing with and
that we're getting these-- we're going to figure out what
the components of a graph are.

And it's amazing how beautifully
everything fits together

because every time
the computer needs to needs to make a decision
or to figure out something,

the information is right there. It's fingertips, and
it hardly has to--

it doesn't have to go over
and do anything twice. It's always doing
two things at once. So I hope you can see that here
we have a case where it's not

just the algorithm
that's interesting, but the way the
algorithm is represented inside a computer that
makes this one special.

And I knew that
theorems can be deep.

I knew that algorithms can
be very, very profound. But this goes further.

It says also the data structure
in an algorithm that can have really non-trivial ideas in it.

OK, so now, what are strong
components and weak components?

I have to-- I might
as well explain that. I hope you know what
a directed graph is.

A directed graph is a bunch
of points connected by arrows,

and for every ordered pair of,
or for certain ordered pair of points, like u and v, will
have an arrow between u and v.

So here, for example,
is a directed graph.

And it's got-- well,
I got one, two, three.

I don't know about
something like 66. 16, 17 vertices.

And then, we've got
arrows here and there.

And we say that two vertices
are in the same strong component if you can get from
one to the other.

You can get from u
to v and back again. So I put little dots around
the strong components here.

These three vertices are in
the same strong component because they can go from here
to here to here, and from here

back to back to here again. These three here--
we have a cycle. Certainly, if you have a cycle
of n vertices, all of them

are in the same strong compound. But here's a case
where there's only one

vertex in the strong
compound by itself. There's lots of
things can get to it, but it can't get
to anything else.

So that is the idea
of a strong component. Now, what about
a weak component?

And here, the story is
a little bit unfortunate because there's a lot of
papers have been written where

people said a weak component. It is just weather you can
get from one to another

without looking-- without
looking at the arrows. You can go either
direction, in which case

this thing would all
be one weak compound. But that spoils the--

so we should call that an
undirected component of a graph
rather than a weak component. But what a weak component--

it is a much more interesting
and useful concept.

And these vertical lines divide
this thing into weak components.

So I think the best way to
think of it is suppose we--

well, OK, everything
in this weak component

can get to everything
in the other three. And everything in
this one can get
to everything, two and three. So this guy can get here.

But nothing in this
component can get back on the other side of the line. So if we shrink a strong
components to a single point,

then we get a graph that has
no cycles in it, no loops.

Imagine that all
these circles, we just made that one super vertex.

So that gives us
an acyclic graph, a graph that has no cycles. But now, suppose we shrink all
the weak components together,

then we get a straight line. One, two, three, four,
or zero, one, two, three.

So that's the idea. It's the most general
partition which

has this property that
gives you a straight line. So people who liked the
phrase partial order says

shrink the strong components,
you get a partial order. Shrink the weak components,
you get a total order
or a linear order.  And that's a nice concept.

Now, I'm glad to say I
looked up on Wikipedia, and for the last two years,
thanks to David Epstein,

there's been a good article on
Wikipedia about weak components. But before that you
would have been--

I was very disappointed
at what Wikipedia said about weak components. So although his
article is excellent,

except it could use
some illustrations, so maybe next week
somebody will improve it

by adding a picture to it. But anyway, that's what I
think mathematically deserves

to be called weak component. And the history is both
interesting and unfortunate

in a way.  The idea of weak
components was invented

by Professor [? Mazkin ?]
while he and Ron Graham

and I were in correspondence
about another problem. And here's a letter that
I got from [? Mazkin. ?]

It's dated 1970, February 28 of
1970, from Mazkin to Ron Graham.

And he says-- in here he'll say
something like for arbitrary,

are-- this is how you
get a total order when you have this partition.

So Ron and I were
working on this problem.

And in December of that year,
1970, I wrote to Ron and I said,

Ron, I got to look at this
problem again yesterday. It turns out that each
member of you, me, and Mazkin

took a different approach
and proved something that is more general
in some sense than what the other two proved.

So I showed one thing,
Ron showed another thing, and Mazkin showed this
thing about weak components.

So anyway, here it says, "I
couldn't have proved this without [? Mazkin's ?]
results, so I

resolved last night to
include him as a joint author. Then, this morning, I received
the unfortunate news of his

sudden death on Tuesday
due to a heart attack." So that's why I said
it's a sad story, too.

So this paper was
published shortly

after [? Mazkin's ?] death. And it came out in this
journal, Discrete Mathematics.

I think it was volume-- yeah, Volume 2, number 1. And so here's the
article about what--

and in that article, they
have a picture actually, which you might recognize
if you turn it this way.

That was 1972 when Discrete
Mathematics was just starting its second volume.

By now, I think it's
in volume 1,000. Anyway, its volumes now
have thousands of pages.

Nobody had it, in their wildest
dreams, believed, in 1972,

how many excellent
papers would eventually be written in that journal
of Discrete Mathematics.

Similarly, Bob Tarjan's
algorithm for strong components

came out not in
Volume 2, number 1, but in Volume 1, number 2 of
SIAM Journal on Computing.

So this was, again,
1972 and the beginning of a huge, wonderful
tradition of papers.

When these journals were
just getting started and nobody really had
any idea how rich--

you have a question? Can you go to the
directed graph? Can I what? [INAUDIBLE] with the directed
graph on the projector?
The previous thing [INAUDIBLE]. So back to the graph? OK, just take a directed graph.
The example. The example of? I'm sorry? [INTERPOSING VOICES]

Yeah. Oh, OK. From what I know,
weakly equivalent is--

I mean [INAUDIBLE] components
are when they are strongly

[INAUDIBLE] or
they're uncomparable. So there's an arrow
from the top--

from the bottom to the
second chunk of [INAUDIBLE] and the first section on top.

Yeah, that one. That's the one. Right, so anyway, if
they're incomparable,

then they have to be
in the same [? weak. ?] From the top of the one on the--
the one up there. [LAUGHTER] You can come down.

I'll tell you what, I'm going
to put names on all these.
In fact, each way, I give names.

Makes the algorithm a
little bit different. So I'm going to put
random numbers in here.

Yeah, so from M to
O, there's an arrow. OK.

OK. So now E-- I'm giving it the letters
A through O. And this was--

I used a random
number generator. [LAUGHTER]

Actually, I have the cutest
random number generator. It's little marbles
inside of a pen.

And you and you
can shake the pen, and then the marbles
go down into a tube. And you can see where it went. But anyway, that's how
I got this ordering.

Now, your question is-- So there's an arrow
from M to O. So why are they the
same parts and--
There's an arrow from N to O? Yeah-- No, it's-- M to O. So--

M to O, yes. So are they part of
the same component?

It's because M is
incomparable with G, and G is incomparable with
O. And so by transitivity,

they're-- so, it's an
equivalence relation. And so if you have a
chain of incomparability,

then they're in the
same weak [? compo. ?] OK. I might as well-- I might as well mention now
that there's this wonderful idea

called topological sorting. So if you have a graph
that has no cycles,

then the topological sorting
is you write the super vertices

like this, but you
write them in such a way that all the arrows are--

all the arrows are going
the same direction. So, one topological
sorting would be like A, O, G, N,
F, J, T. But there are

other topological sortings too. I could start with this one
and then I could go here. I could go here first and--

well, I guess I got to do-- after O-- well, anyway,
you choose a source

and then you throw it away
and you choose another source. OK, now, if you
look at all the--

if you look at all the
topological sortings, if x is always in front
of y in all of them,

then they're in different
weak components. But if some of them have x
before y and some of them have y before x, then they're
in the same weak component.

So OK. Now going back to the history
of it, Bob published--

Bob Tarjan published
his algorithm in the first volume of
Siam Journal on Computing.

And this-- yeah, this is number
6 on his list of publications. He was a grad
student at the time.
And I read it at the end of-- in January of 1973.

I looked at my diary and I-- and the previous week, I
had written this novelette

called Surreal Numbers. And then on Monday the
next, I came back to work and I started looking
at this journal,

and I found this algorithm
and decided I loved it. OK, now-- and so the algorithm,
it's one of two algorithms here.

And he's got-- explained
there and so on.

And it's not exactly the
algorithm I'm going to-- we've improved it
over the years. But I did want to show you this,
which was the math review that

came out of the algorithm. It says the author first
describes the algorithm for finding strongly
connected components.

And he says this algorithm
takes linear time

and it's not very surprising. So the reviewer was not
at all impressed with it.

And so there's no
accounting for taste. But I do hope that by the
time I finish today, you'll
get some idea of why I like it. OK, now let's see what's next.

Oh, yeah, how are
we doing on time?
OK, I want to spend a certain-- I want to spend like 45--

well, let's see, we've already
used almost 10 minutes. So anyway, let's try to go 35--

15 or something of 35
on strong components and 15 on weak components
or something like that.

That's what I'm
trying to shoot for. The algorithm was
very well described

in the first great
textbook on algorithms by Aho, Hopcroft, and Ullman.

John Hopcroft actually
was part of the invention

of this algorithm. John came out to Stanford
for his sabbatical year.

And well, we didn't have
that much office space, so he shared an office
with Bob Tarjan.

Bob was a grad student, and John
was our visitor from Cornell. And they got to talking
and they invented all kinds

of beautiful algorithms. And, John, especially
had a good algorithm

for finding not the strong
components of a directed graph, but the biconnected components
of an undirected graph.

And then he showed
that to Tarjan,

and Tarjan said, oh, yeah,
we can use a similar idea for strong components. And the rest is history.

And so they have a good
description in here

of Tarjan's algorithm, which
is, as I say, it's subtle.

It takes a while-- it
takes a while to get it. I'm not going to be
able to explain it

so that you just understand. But if you have time to look at
it and realize why it wasn't--

why it's not trivial, then some
of my goal will be achieved.

This book came out later
in the '50s by Shimon Even,

who went to Cornell and worked
with Bob in the early '70s.

And let's see if I can-- where does he describe
Bob's algorithm?
He had this very nice idea. Let's see where-- trees.

Here we go. Strong component, 64. So, anyway, it
says the algorithm

involves something that in this
book is called the low point. And he says, it seems
like a circular situation.

In order to compute
the low point, we need to identify
the components. And in order to
find the components,

we need the low point. However, Tarjan found a way out. And that's the reference to
the subtlety of this method.

So the best way I
know to explain it is to try to go through--

and again ask me questions
if you want clarification.

Now I'm going to-- I'm going to imagine that
we're given this directed graph

and we want to figure
out its strong component. And so I'm going to write
down the edges of the graph

quickly here. A, B, C, D, E, F, G H, I, J
K, L, M, N, O. That's enough.

OK, now-- so I just have
to put all the arcs.

So A-- here's one from A to
M, and then there's one from M to A. And then there's
D to M and M to D. O--
M to O, right.  OK.

OK, O to N. O to B. O to F.
N goes to J. J goes to L.

And B-- this is a
B. OK, let's see.

B doesn't go to anything. G goes to K. K goes to H. H goes
to G and C. OK, C goes to F.

And F goes to L and C. It
matters which one I put first.

I mean the algorithms are going
to find the strong components in either case, but it's
going to behave differently

because the computer
only sees this list. It doesn't have a
picture of the thing.

The computer is going blind. And the best way I tend to
think of it, E goes to I
and I goes to itself. So I go to-- OK, now I think that's it.
Did I miss anything? K to N. K to-- N. N. OK, I'm glad somebody--

yeah, I'd like to say I did that
on purpose, but just to see-- but the fact is I missed it.

OK. [INAUDIBLE] All right. Now so I think it's a good
idea to imagine that you're

playing an adventure game. You're in a cave. And this cave has different
rooms, A, B, C up to O.

And for each room, you have
different rooms you can move to.

And the-- and so we want
to explore this cave and find out what its
strong components are.

OK, so-- and in
general, the algorithm

that we're going to use is
called depth first search, which is a good way to
explore any cave or any graph.

Hi. I think L to J is
missing and probably has to come before the E? L-- L to I--

J. L to J, right, and
L to E. Very good.

to 23. Yes, I remember
that was the number. Very good. OK, now so we're going to try
to do like any good spelunking

exploring a cave. But well, the computer,
it's only given these lists

and it has to try to
visualize everything. Just given this data.

And now-- but
inside the computer,

I imagine that each vertex-- that this is a linear
list, like A first, then B,

then C, and so on. And then for each vertex in
this linear list of vertices

has a list of arcs going out. And this can be stored
in different ways.

But I'm going to say
that the first thing I do is I have to get in
the cave somewhere.

So I look at the largest vertex
and I'm going to go all the way. So I'm going to first look
at O. And I'm going to say--

so I'm going to start
exploring the cave at O. And this method is called
depth first research.

And so the idea is we imagine
that we're sitting somewhere

in the cave. I'm sitting at position O. And
I look at the next outlet from O

that I haven't
looked at yet before. So the first one is N. And
so from O, I go to N. OK,

and now I'm in N. And from
N, I go to J. Oh, sorry.
Better underline it. Watch me that I underline. From J, I go to L.

This can be boring unless we--
unless something new happens. I, I hear something new. From L, it says go to J. And he
says, oh, I've been to J before.

So this-- when
you're in a cave, you can leave some kind of a
litter behind or something

so that you know that
you've been there before. So from L to J, we're going to--

I'm going to put this
as a dotted line.

I won't bother to
write the arrowhead.

Now when we do a
depth first search, there are five kinds of-- there are five kinds of arcs.

And so they're
called a tree arc.

Can you see what I wrote? Tree arc, a back
arc, and there are

three-- there are three other
kinds we're going to get to. So the tree arc, we
have ON, NJ, and JL.
And then the back arc was LJ. All right. Now so LJ, stands next is LE.

So here comes E. So
that's a tree arc.

And from E, this set
I, believe it or not.

So we got from E to
I another tree arc.

I goes to I. Here's
a new kind of arc. It's called a loop.
So II is a loop.

It's not-- loops don't do
anything for strong components. It doesn't change
reachability at all.

You could remove all
the loops and then you still get the same
strong components. But anyway, you do run
into them sometimes.

So here was the loop. And now, E to I.
OK, now what next?

I'm still at I. And
I finished with I,

so nothing more to see from I.
So at this point, since there's

nothing coming out
of I, I'm going to declare that I is
a strong component.
You've got a question. Hi. What about underlining JL? What about underlining JL?
Very good. Yeah, OK.

So anyway, so I'm going to
declare this a strong component.
I got it. Now, and I go back--

I unwind to the previous
thing on the tree. How did I get here to I?

And so here's
something you can't do in your adventure games. Sometimes you can't-- to
get from one to another,

you fall off a hill. You can't unfall off a
cliff, but the computer can.

So we go back to E. And E-- we're also done
with E. So, well,

let's declare that to be a
strong component as well. Now L-- We've seen J.
But oops, I've also--

I forgot, so I'm
done with L as well.

But I'm not going
to declare this to be a strong component because
I know that I can get out of it. So one important thing is--

maybe the most important
thing is that if-- when we shrink all the
strong components to a point,

we got a graph with no cycles. And it's called directed
acyclic graph DAG, D-A-G.

And in that case,
you always have-- you always have sinks.

That means that there's
some-- if there's no cycle and it's a finite graph,
then eventually, you

get to something
that has no escape. A black hole. You can't get out--
you can't get out of it. So E was a sink.

And so I could take
it out of the graph. If you take it out of the graph,
then the remaining problem

is to find the strong components
on the remaining graph. And so eventually, the
strong components--

we're going to remove one sink
strong component at a time until we've removed everything.

OK, but now L is not a-- but L by itself had branches
out of it, so it is not a sink.

I go back to J and-- but J, I haven't seen
anything else, any way out.

So I can declare that J and
L is a strong component.

OK, wait a minute. I'm sorry. Whoops, whoops,
whoops, whoops, whoops.

I'm sorry. J, I have to-- I still have to
explore to be here. And then B is going
to be a strong--

B is a strong component. Now I can come back and I
can declare J [INAUDIBLE].

OK. So, right. In fact, I have to get-- I have to-- I have
to get a sink.

I remove this sink,
I remove this sink. There's only one sink left. So I got to remove
this thing next.

OK, and then J L is
going to go away. All right. So let's see.

JB was a tree arc. Professor. Yeah. And how does the
algorithm now know

that L and J are a component? Is there a stack
that it maintains? So you see, I proved
that it's a sink,
because there's nothing there. It doesn't go into anything.

I mean, the computer has
to know at this point-- I mean, I've drawn it here.

And I'm using clairvoyance. Tarjan's secret sauce
is going to tell us how to really do this.

But what I mean is,
how does it know which vertices belong to it? Does it have a stack
of the ones that--

so L, this would be on
the stack or something? What I actually-- what I
actually have in the algorithm

is a stack of all the stuff
that I haven't put a box around.

And that stack has
things linked together. You're right.

And the two top things on the
stack are L and J. And somehow,
I'm going to know that nothing-- neither L nor J has an outlet.

But I'm glad you-- because
that's exactly the point that we're trying to get. OK, so anyway, I think
I'm done with J now.

And so I go back to
N. And N is done.

And so O is-- next is
B. But O goes to B.
This is a new kind of arc. It's called a forward arc, OB.
And then, OF, that's new.
So OF comes over here. And F goes to--
OF is a tree arc. And then F to C is a tree arc. And C to F is a back arc.
And then FL is the next one.

But FL goes to one of
the strong components

that we've already
removed from the graph. We call those guys settled. And so this is
called a cross arc.

And that's the fifth
kind of arc here. So it's not in the tree.

It doesn't go backward
to an ancestor. It doesn't go forward
to a descendant.

It goes across to
somebody who's neither an ancestor nor descendant.

And so-- well, we're almost
done, so I might as well-- I might as well finish it.

So C-- C goes back to F. And
then F went to C and then L.

And so now we're done with
F. And then O is done.
So I'm all done. And I've got this tree.

But I haven't seen it--
seen the whole graph yet. So I started at O. Now,
there's another way

to get into the cave that's
not reachable from O. And so I go back.

And so O is all finished. N is all finished. Next, I do M. So I
start a new tree with M.

And M then is going to go
to A. And A comes back to M.
And then M goes to D.

So M goes to D and then D
goes back to M. So these--
and when I get back to M--

I'm sorry, M still has to go
to O. But O is a cross arc.

So at this point,
I'm going to declare MAD to be a strong component.

Interesting, because I wasn't
supposed to be able to do that.

Because it leaves--
it leads to O, which--
so what happened? Oh, I see. I see. I forgot to declare these guys.

I should have declared F
and C and N, and then O. OK.

So I forgot. So yeah, because
I'm not a computer.

I'm a human being. [LAUGHTER] OK, now so we've done M, A,
D, O. And going back, H is--
still haven't seen H. H [INAUDIBLE]. What? H [INAUDIBLE]. K.
K is an arc to N. K is out there. Very good. K is out there.

I see. This is not an
underline under the H. It's the upper line of a J.
OK, so K goes to H. Right.

And H goes to G,
which you've seen. No, which we haven't seen.

And G goes to K. OK, so K goes
to H, H goes to G, G goes to--

this is a back arc that
goes not to your parent but to your grandparent.

And right-- now this object
here is, in general, it's
called the depth first forest.  A forest is a bunch of trees.

And most years, my
Christmas lecture has something to do with trees.

And again this year, we got
Christmas trees coming in here. So the depth first forest in
this case has three trees.

One of them is rooted
at O, another one at M, and another one at
K. And in general,

if I had given
different names to these or put these
different order, then

I would have got a different
depth first forest. But each ordering defines
a depth first forest which

you can prove things about. And each depth, this
forest has its tree arcs and back arcs and so on.

And a lot of algorithms can
be based on the properties of this kind of arc.

OK, question? Yeah. Since [? before ?] can
cross arcs, they are--

The four what? We don't need to
distinguish between the two. How do I distinguish what? Cross arc. A cross arc?

Yes. Because basically, when
we say every cross-- [INTERPOSING VOICES] We do nothing. So I don't do--

a cross arc is just one that-- it's not a tree arc
and it doesn't go
to an ancestor or a descendant.

So like F to L, L is not an
ancestor of F or a descendant

of F. They're both
descendants of O. They have a common
ancestor, but they're--

but they might not even
have a common ancestor.

So-- It's about whether or not the F
and L are ancestors [? fought ?]

for each other. It doesn't matter
for this algorithm.

So if we see O points to D,
or if we see F points to L,

that doesn't affect the flow. It doesn't affect the
strong components,
